statement: G. Even-Odd XORtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputGiven an integer $$$n$$$, find any array $$$a$$$ of $$$n$$$distinctnonnegative integers less than $$$2^{31}$$$ such that thebitwise XORof the elements on odd indices equals the bitwise XOR of the elements on even indices.InputThe first line of the input contains an integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 629$$$) — the number of test cases.Then $$$t$$$ lines follow, each containing a single integer $$$n$$$ $$$(3 \\leq n \\leq 2\\cdot10^5)$$$ — the length of the array.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$2\\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case, output one line containing $$$n$$$ distinct integers that satisfy the conditions.If there are multiple answers, you can output any of them.ExampleInput7 8 3 4 5 6 7 9Output4 2 1 5 0 6 7 3 2 1 3 2 1 3 0 2 0 4 5 3 4 1 2 12 3 8 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 2 3 7 4 0 5 6 9NoteIn the first test case the XOR on odd indices is $$$4 \\oplus 1 \\oplus 0 \\oplus 7 = 2$$$ and the XOR on even indices is $$$2 \\oplus 5 \\oplus 6 \\oplus 3= 2$$$.

Given an integer $n$, find an array of $n$ distinct non-negative integers less than $2^{31}$ such that the bitwise XOR of the elements at odd indices equals the bitwise XOR of the elements at even indices. 

Input:

* The first line contains an integer $t$ ($1 \leq t \leq 629$) - the number of test cases.
* Each of the next $t$ lines contains an integer $n$ ($3 \leq n \leq 2 \cdot 10^5$) - the length of the array.
* The sum of $n$ over all test cases does not exceed $2 \cdot 10^5$.

Output:

* For each test case, output one line containing $n$ distinct integers that satisfy the conditions. Any valid answer is acceptable.
Given a number, find a list of distinct numbers that add up to that number in a specific way.  The sum of the numbers at odd positions must equal the sum of the numbers at even positions.
